articles.headline: Greek Crisis Leaves Cyprus Mired in Debt
articles.snippet: Cypriot banks have to prove their viability as the total of their risky investments has reached eight times the size of their nation’s economy.
articles.abstract: Cypriot banks have to prove their viability as the total of their risky investments has reached eight times the size of their nation’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Michalis Sarris is not the only European banker working seven days a week, trying to scrape together enough capital to satisfy regulators and keep his institution afloat. But he may be the only one with the financial fate of his nation potentially hanging in the balance.

articles.headline: A Buffet of Magazines on a Tablet
articles.snippet: The Next Issue app, available for some Android tablets, offers unlimited downloads of a host of popular magazines for one flat fee.
articles.abstract: The Next Issue app, available for some Android tablets, offers unlimited downloads of a host of popular magazines for one flat fee.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few words fire up the happiness transmitters in your brain more than “free.” But “flat-fee unlimited” comes close.

articles.headline: Few U.S. Options as North Korea Readies Missile Launching
articles.snippet: The White House is trying to play down the propaganda value for North Korea’s leaders and is readying a response, which could include suspending a food-aid agreement.
articles.abstract: The White House is trying to play down the propaganda value for North Korea’s leaders and is readying a response, which could include suspending a food-aid agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With North Korea poised to launch a long-range missile despite a widespread international protest, the Obama administration is trying to play down the propaganda value for North Korea’s leaders and head off criticism of its abortive diplomatic opening to Pyongyang in late February.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: At St. Jude, Firing Back at Critics
articles.snippet: St. Jude Medical is defending itself against reports of deaths and injuries linked to an implanted heart device made by the company.
articles.abstract: St. Jude Medical is defending itself against reports of deaths and injuries linked to an implanted heart device made by the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: As St. Jude Medical defends itself against reports of deaths and injuries linked to problems with an implanted heart device, it finds itself in familiar territory. Since 2005, two competitors, Medtronic and Guidant, have faced similar scrutiny about critical flaws in their products.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Prosecutor Files Charge of 2nd-Degree Murder in Shooting of Martin
articles.snippet: The special prosecutor in the shooting death of the 17-year-old in Sanford, Fla., said Wednesday that George Zimmerman would appear before a magistrate in the next 24 hours.
articles.abstract: The special prosecutor in the shooting death of the 17-year-old in Sanford, Fla., said Wednesday that George Zimmerman would appear before a magistrate in the next 24 hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — More than six weeks after he shot and killed Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old with no criminal record, George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch coordinator at a small gated community in Sanford, Fla., was charged by a special prosecutor on Wednesday evening with second-degree murder and taken into custody.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: J.&J. Fined $1.2 Billion in Drug Case
articles.snippet: A judge fined Johnson & Johnson and a subsidiary after a jury found that the companies minimized or concealed the dangers associated with Risperdal, an antipsychotic drug.
articles.abstract: A judge fined Johnson & Johnson and a subsidiary after a jury found that the companies minimized or concealed the dangers associated with Risperdal, an antipsychotic drug.
articles.lead_paragraph: A judge in Arkansas ordered Johnson & Johnson and a subsidiary to pay more than $1.2 billion in fines on Wednesday, a day after a jury found that the companies had minimized or concealed the dangers associated with an antipsychotic drug.

articles.headline: Romney Taking Steps to Narrow His Gender Gap
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s campaign finds itself squeezed between its intensifying efforts to appeal to women and its need to avoid alienating conservatives.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s campaign finds itself squeezed between its intensifying efforts to appeal to women and its need to avoid alienating conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney moved Wednesday to confront one of his most vexing general election problems — how to narrow the gender gap he faces against President Obama — but his campaign immediately found itself squeezed between its intensifying efforts to appeal to women and its need to avoid alienating conservatives.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Cut in E-Book Pricing by Amazon Is Set to Shake Rivals
articles.snippet: The government’s decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put Amazon, the nation’s largest bookseller, in a powerful position to decide how much an e-book will cost.
articles.abstract: The government’s decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put Amazon, the nation’s largest bookseller, in a powerful position to decide how much an e-book will cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put the Internet retailer Amazon in a powerful position: the nation’s largest bookseller may now get to decide how much an e-book will cost, and the book world is quaking over the potential consequences.

articles.headline: Briton’s Wanderings Led Him to Heart of a Chinese Scandal
articles.snippet: Neil Heywood’s ties to Bo Xilai and his family may have cost him his life and set off China’s biggest political scandal in a generation. But precisely why, or how, he died is still unknown.
articles.abstract: Neil Heywood’s ties to Bo Xilai and his family may have cost him his life and set off China’s biggest political scandal in a generation. But precisely why, or how, he died is still unknown.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — At St. Mary’s Church in London’s Thames-side Battersea district, mourners who gathered for Neil Heywood’s memorial service a few days before Christmas were perplexed by the instructions laid down beforehand by one of Mr. Heywood’s classmates from Britain’s elite Harrow boarding school. He asked them not to approach Lulu Heywood, Mr. Heywood’s Chinese wife, and to remain in the pews until she and their two children had left the church.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and John F. Burns

articles.headline: In Struggling Spanish Town, Hopes of Reopening Mine Are Delayed
articles.snippet: A plan to reopen a mine in Spain has been stalled, angering local residents in need of jobs while leaving environmentalists worried that economic priorities will trump safety concerns.
articles.abstract: A plan to reopen a mine in Spain has been stalled, angering local residents in need of jobs while leaving environmentalists worried that economic priorities will trump safety concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINAS DE RIOTINTO, Spain — The Riotinto mine in the Andalusia region of southern Spain was once the world’s largest copper producer, a British-owned operation that helped fuel the Industrial Revolution and gave its name to a mining giant that remains one of the world’s biggest commodities producers.
